section.title: Quantities
section.para:
Concrete domains are a construct that can define new classes by specifying restrictions on attributes that have literal values (as opposed to relationships to other concepts). The binary operators, equal to, greater than, greater than or equal to, less than, and less than or equal to, can be used in concrete domain expressions, and literal values can be integers, floating point numbers, string literals, and dates.
SNOROCKET 2.0 Concurrent Domains and Concurrent Classification
Concrete domains are used to model quantities in the definition of concepts, such as defining how much ibuprofen may be in a medication tablet.
